Comment: At the moment I prefer to play against d4 then e4 because I am in the proccess of 'booking up' on the petroff defense.

My two big choices here are either 3... b5 or e6 (as I did play), b5 being the benko and e6 being the benoni. I personally opt for the benoni because I feel I have more opening knowledge on the benoni but the benko I still perfectly reasonable.

This is an interesting move. At first this is very weakening because after 9.Nxe5 dxe5 white will have a nice outpost on d5 which good come into good use later but it turns out that this pawn may of cost him the match.

Here I spend 45 minutes contemplating this move, can you see why? I was looking at a couple of variations including 17...Nh5 or B/Ng4. If Nh5 then white can just proceed with e5 or Rh4 (both of these are acceptable). I thought that the must surely be some way of me trapping his rook but even the computer says not.

He falls into my trap, Qe3 would of probably been a better choice.
This forces a loss of a piece. If 20.Bxc4 then Qc5+ wins it and if Be2 then Qb6 wins the b2 pawn which forks the knight and rook.
